trans-unit.source: Reserved IP
trans-unit.target: Reserved IP

trans-unit.source: Understand reserved IPs, VIP, ILPIP, and how to manage them
trans-unit.target: Understand reserved IPs, VIP, ILPIP, and how to manage them

trans-unit.source: Reserved IP Overview
trans-unit.target: Reserved IP Overview

trans-unit.source: IP addresses in Azure fall into two categories: dynamic and reserved.
trans-unit.target: IP addresses in Azure fall into two categories: dynamic and reserved.

trans-unit.source: Public IP addresses managed by Azure are dynamic by default.
trans-unit.target: Public IP addresses managed by Azure are dynamic by default.

trans-unit.source: That means that the IP address used for a given cloud service (VIP) or to access a VM or role instance directly (ILPIP) can change from time to time, when resources are shutdown or deallocated.
trans-unit.target: That means that the IP address used for a given cloud service (VIP) or to access a VM or role instance directly (ILPIP) can change from time to time, when resources are shutdown or deallocated.

trans-unit.source: To prevent IP addresses from changing, you can reserve an IP address.
trans-unit.target: To prevent IP addresses from changing, you can reserve an IP address.

trans-unit.source: Reserved IPs can be used only as a VIP, ensuring that the IP address for the cloud service will be the same even as resources are shutdown or deallocated.
trans-unit.target: Reserved IPs can be used only as a VIP, ensuring that the IP address for the cloud service will be the same even as resources are shutdown or deallocated.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, you can convert existing dynamic IPs used as a VIP to a reserved IP address.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, you can convert existing dynamic IPs used as a VIP to a reserved IP address.

trans-unit.source: When do I need a reserved IP?
trans-unit.target: When do I need a reserved IP?

trans-unit.source: **You want to ensure that the IP is reserved in your subscription**.
trans-unit.target: **You want to ensure that the IP is reserved in your subscription**.

trans-unit.source: If you want to reserve an IP address that will not be released from your subscription under any circumstance, you should use a reserved public IP.
trans-unit.target: If you want to reserve an IP address that will not be released from your subscription under any circumstance, you should use a reserved public IP.

trans-unit.source: **You want your IP to stay with your cloud service even across stopped or deallocated state (VMs)**.
trans-unit.target: **You want your IP to stay with your cloud service even across stopped or deallocated state (VMs)**.

trans-unit.source: If you want your service to be accessed by using an IP address that will not change even when VMs in the cloud service are stop or deallocated.
trans-unit.target: If you want your service to be accessed by using an IP address that will not change even when VMs in the cloud service are stop or deallocated.

trans-unit.source: **You want to ensure that outbound traffic from Azure uses a predictable IP address**.
trans-unit.target: **You want to ensure that outbound traffic from Azure uses a predictable IP address**.

trans-unit.source: You may have your on-premises firewall configured to allow only traffic from specific IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: You may have your on-premises firewall configured to allow only traffic from specific IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: By reserving an IP, you will know the source IP address and won’t have to update your firewall rules due to an IP change.
trans-unit.target: By reserving an IP, you will know the source IP address and won’t have to update your firewall rules due to an IP change.

trans-unit.source: FAQ
trans-unit.target: FAQ

trans-unit.source: Can I use a reserved IP for all Azure services?
trans-unit.target: Can I use a reserved IP for all Azure services?

trans-unit.source: Reserved IPs can only be used for VMs and cloud service instance roles.
trans-unit.target: Reserved IPs can only be used for VMs and cloud service instance roles.

trans-unit.source: How many reserved IPs can I have?
trans-unit.target: How many reserved IPs can I have?

trans-unit.source: At this time, all Azure subscriptions are authorized to use 20 reserved IPs.
trans-unit.target: At this time, all Azure subscriptions are authorized to use 20 reserved IPs.

trans-unit.source: However, you can request additional reserved IPs.
trans-unit.target: However, you can request additional reserved IPs.

trans-unit.source: See the [Subscription and Service Limits](../azure-subscription-service-limits/) page for more information.
trans-unit.target: See the [Subscription and Service Limits](../azure-subscription-service-limits/) page for more information.

trans-unit.source: Is there a charge for reserved IPs?
trans-unit.target: Is there a charge for reserved IPs?

trans-unit.source: See [Reserved IP Address Pricing Details](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=398482) for pricing information.
trans-unit.target: See [Reserved IP Address Pricing Details](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=398482) for pricing information.

trans-unit.source: How do I reserve an IP address?
trans-unit.target: How do I reserve an IP address?

trans-unit.source: You can use PowerShell or the [Azure Management REST API](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn722420.aspx) to request a reserved IP from a particular region.
trans-unit.target: You can use PowerShell or the [Azure Management REST API](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn722420.aspx) to request a reserved IP from a particular region.

trans-unit.source: Azure will reserve an IP address from that region and correlate it to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Azure will reserve an IP address from that region and correlate it to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can then use the reserved IP in that region.
trans-unit.target: You can then use the reserved IP in that region.

trans-unit.source: You cannot reserve an IP address by using the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: You cannot reserve an IP address by using the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Can I use this with affinity group based VNets?
trans-unit.target: Can I use this with affinity group based VNets?

trans-unit.source: Reserved IPs are only supported in regional VNets.
trans-unit.target: Reserved IPs are only supported in regional VNets.

trans-unit.source: It is not supported for VNets that are associated with affinity groups.
trans-unit.target: It is not supported for VNets that are associated with affinity groups.

trans-unit.source: For more information about associating a VNet with a region or an affinity group, see [About Regional VNets and Affinity Groups](virtual-networks-migrate-to-regional-vnet.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about associating a VNet with a region or an affinity group, see [About Regional VNets and Affinity Groups](virtual-networks-migrate-to-regional-vnet.md).

trans-unit.source: How to manage reserved VIPs
trans-unit.target: How to manage reserved VIPs

trans-unit.source: Before you can use reserved IPs, you must add it to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Before you can use reserved IPs, you must add it to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: To create a reserved IP from the pool of public IP addresses available in the *Central US* location, run the following PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To create a reserved IP from the pool of public IP addresses available in the *Central US* location, run the following PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: Notice, however, that you cannot specify what IP is being reserved.
trans-unit.target: Notice, however, that you cannot specify what IP is being reserved.

trans-unit.source: To view what IP addresses are reserved in your subscription, run the following PowerShell command, and notice the values for *ReservedIPName* and *Address*:
trans-unit.target: To view what IP addresses are reserved in your subscription, run the following PowerShell command, and notice the values for *ReservedIPName* and *Address*:

trans-unit.source: Once an IP is reserved, it remains associated to your subscription until you delete it.
trans-unit.target: Once an IP is reserved, it remains associated to your subscription until you delete it.

trans-unit.source: To delete the reserved IP shown above, run the following PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To delete the reserved IP shown above, run the following PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: How to associate a reserved IP to a new cloud service
trans-unit.target: How to associate a reserved IP to a new cloud service

trans-unit.source: The script below creates a new reserved IP, then associates it to a new cloud service named *TestService*.
trans-unit.target: The script below creates a new reserved IP, then associates it to a new cloud service named *TestService*.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] When you create a reserved IP to use with a cloud service, you’ll still need to refer to the VM by using *VIP:<port number>* for inbound communication.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] When you create a reserved IP to use with a cloud service, you’ll still need to refer to the VM by using *VIP:<port number>* for inbound communication.

trans-unit.source: Reserving an IP does not mean you can connect to the VM directly.
trans-unit.target: Reserving an IP does not mean you can connect to the VM directly.

trans-unit.source: The reserved IP is assigned to the cloud service that the VM has been deployed to.
trans-unit.target: The reserved IP is assigned to the cloud service that the VM has been deployed to.

trans-unit.source: If you want to connect to a VM by IP directly, you have to configure an instance-level public IP.
trans-unit.target: If you want to connect to a VM by IP directly, you have to configure an instance-level public IP.

trans-unit.source: An instance-level public IP is a type of public IP (called a ILPIP) that is assigned directly to your VM.
trans-unit.target: An instance-level public IP is a type of public IP (called a ILPIP) that is assigned directly to your VM.

trans-unit.source: It cannot be reserved.
trans-unit.target: It cannot be reserved.

trans-unit.source: See [Instance-level Public IP (ILPIP)](../virtual-networks-instance-level-public-ip) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [Instance-level Public IP (ILPIP)](../virtual-networks-instance-level-public-ip) for more information.

trans-unit.source: How to remove a reserved IP from a running deployment
trans-unit.target: How to remove a reserved IP from a running deployment

trans-unit.source: To remove the reserved IP added to the new service created in the script above, run the following PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To remove the reserved IP added to the new service created in the script above, run the following PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Removing a reserved IP from a running deployment does not remove the reservation from your subscription.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Removing a reserved IP from a running deployment does not remove the reservation from your subscription.

trans-unit.source: It simply frees the IP to be used by another resource in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: It simply frees the IP to be used by another resource in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: How to associate a reserved IP to a running deployment
trans-unit.target: How to associate a reserved IP to a running deployment

trans-unit.target: The script below creates a new cloud service named *TestService2* with a new VM named *TestVM2*, and then associates the existing reserved IP named *MyReservedIP* to the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: How to associate a reserved IP to a cloud service by using a service configuration file
trans-unit.target: How to associate a reserved IP to a cloud service by using a service configuration file

trans-unit.source: You can also associate a reserved IP to a cloud service by using a service configuration (CSCFG) file.
trans-unit.target: You can also associate a reserved IP to a cloud service by using a service configuration (CSCFG) file.
